questions.text: What is the investigation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• The image shows a contrast-enhanced study of the urinary tract- with opacification of the renal calyces, pelvis, ureters, and bladder, which is characteristic of IVP.
  • IVP is a traditional imaging modality where intravenous contrast is used to outline the urinary system on serial X-rays.
  • Used for detecting urinary tract obstructions, stones, and structural anomalies.

Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP)

Feature

Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP)

Modality

X-ray with IV contrast

Indications

Urinary stones, hydronephrosis, congenital anomalies

Procedure

Contrast injected → serial X-rays taken at intervals

Findings

Normal renal function, filling defects, delayed excretion

 

Retrograde Pyelogram (Option B): Incorrect because contrast is introduced via a ureteric catheter, not IV, and it primarily evaluates the lower urinary tract.

CT Urography (Option C): Incorrect because CT urography provides cross-sectional images with better resolution and 3D reconstruction, unlike IVP, which is a plain X-ray-based study.

Magnetic Resonance Urography (Option D): Incorrect because MR urography is non-ionizing, uses T2-weighted sequences, and does not show contrast excretion in real-time like IVP.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child presents with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections, poor urinary stream, and failure to thrive. On examination, his abdomen is distended, and there is a palpable bladder. His MCU is given below. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cystoscopic resection:

  • Cystoscopic resection is the treatment of choice for Posterior Urethral Valve (PUV), which is a congenital condition characterized by abnormal valve-like folds in the posterior urethra, leading to urinary obstruction.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not appropriate for initial management of PUV.

questions.text: Based on the CT scan shown below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Polycystic kidney disease:

  • The given image shows one large cyst and multiple small cysts in the left kidney, which is suggestive of polycystic kidney disease.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Renal cyst: Renal cyst will show a unilocular cystic lesion.

Option B - Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma will appear as a renal lesion with heterogeneous areas of enhancement.

Option D - Renal angiomyolipoma: Angiomyolipoma will give a dirty black appearance with areas of hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and left flank pain. CT scan of the abdomen was performed and the image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Horseshoe kidney:

  • In a horseshoe kidney, during fetal development, the lower poles of both kidneys fuse, creating a U-shaped structure that is located below the level of the normal kidneys.
  • CT scan shows the fusion of the lower poles of the kidneys, with both kidneys located in proximity in the midline of the abdomen, appearing as a single mass.

Incorrect options: Option B, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of correct answer.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, and the x-ray showed the following features. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Putty kidney

Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows a calcified mass of the right kidney, often referred to as "putty-like," indicating dystrophic calcification. Putty kidney is seen in advanced renal tuberculosis, where extensive calcification and atrophy lead to a non-functioning kidney.

 

Calcifications in the Kidney:

Description

Staghorn Calculus

 

Putty Kidney (Option A)

Medullary Nephrocalcinosis

Description

Large, branching stone filling the renal pelvis and calyces, resembling the shape of a staghorn.

Tissue damage in the kidney by TB leads to dystrophic calcification. Indicates end-stage renal TB.

Calcium deposition within the renal medulla (inner kidney).

Cause

Struvite stones formed from magnesium ammonium phosphate due to infection with urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Klebsiella, Proteus)

Renal tuberculosis leads to granuloma formation causing necrosis, cavitation, fibrosis and stricture formation.

Metabolic disturbances (e.g., hyperparathyroidism, sarcoidosis, renal tubular acidosis, medullary sponge kidney disease) leading to calcification of the renal medulla

Imaging Characteristics

Radio-opaque, visible on CT. They often form rapidly; fill the renal pelvis and extend into calyces. (Option B ruled out)

Appears as a lobulated mass of calcified tissue on CT scans, resembling "putty"; indicating a non-functioning kidney.

Detected on plain radiographs, ultrasound, and CT. USG and CT are very specific and hence useful even in mild cases

  • USG- hyperechoic renal parenchyma with posterior acoustic shadowing.

 

  • CT- High-density renal parenchyma in the medulla (Option C ruled out)

Psoas calcification (Option D): Psoas calcification typically refers to calcification within the psoas muscle or tendon, and it's usually associated with chronic inflammation.

questions.text: In the case presented, can you identify the imaging technique employed and the specific diagnosis related to the kidneys?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MRI of Polycystic Kidney Disease

Explanation:

  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is a preferred modality for diagnosing Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD) due to its superior soft tissue contrast and ability to visualize multiple cysts without ionizing radiation.

Imaging of Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD)

Imaging Modality

Findings

Indications

Ultrasound (USG)

Enlarged kidneys, multiple cysts

First-line screening in suspected PKD

CT Scan

Multiple cysts, hemorrhage, infection

Detects complications like rupture or infection

MRI

High-resolution imaging of cysts, no radiation

Preferred for assessing renal function and disease progression

MRI is particularly useful in young patients and those requiring long-term follow-up.

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

  • Familial disorder with autosomal dominant inheritance, classified as a ciliopathy.
  • Kidneys are progressively replaced by multiple cysts in the cortex and medulla, with initial preservation of intervening parenchyma.
  • ADPKD is typically diagnosed between ages 30 and 50, when symptoms first appear, thus being named "adult PKD”.
  • Typically presents in adults with hematuria, hypertension, and renal failure.
  • It is associated with other conditions namely intracranial aneurysms, heart valve dysfunctions, colonic diverticula, aortic dissection and cystic lesions in other organs like the liver, spleen and pancreas.

Imaging

Plain Radiograph
  • Enlarged, multilobulated renal outlines with bowel displacement.
  • Multiple calcifications, sometimes with multiple ring appearance.
  • Intravenous urography: "Swiss cheese nephrogram" (due to multiple renal cysts), "Spiderleg pyelogram" (stretched pelvicalyceal system).

Ultrasound
  • Simple cysts: Anechoic with thin walls, posterior acoustic enhancement, and lateral shadowing.
  • Complicated cysts (haemorrhage/infection): Echogenic material within the cyst, possible wall calcification, absence of internal blood flow.
  • CEUS: Demonstrates enhancement

CT
  • Simple cysts: Rounded with near-water attenuation and thin walls.
  • Complications (haemorrhage/infection): Higher attenuation and wall calcification.

CT showing ADPKD

 

MRI
  • T2 MRI- The most sensitive imaging modality
  • Both enlarged kidneys have multiple cysts

MRI showing ADPKD

 

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD):

  • It is a hereditary condition seen in infants.
  • There is dilatation of renal tubules.
  • Several tiny cysts (<2mm) are seen scattered throughout the renal parenchyma giving the kidney a striated appearance.
  • X-ray: Bilateral flank masses due to nephromegaly (enlarged kidneys).
  • USG: Kidneys are predominantly hyperechoic with loss of corticomedullary differentiation.
  • CT imaging: Shows smooth, enlarged kidneys with a striated pattern of contrast excretion. The striated pattern signifies the collection of contrast in dilated renal tubules.

 

CT of Polycystic Kidney Disease (Option B): Incorrect because MRI provides better cyst delineation and avoids radiation exposure.

MRI of Horseshoe Kidney (Option C): Incorrect because horseshoe kidney is a congenital fusion anomaly and does not present with numerous cysts as seen in PKD.

CT of Horseshoe Kidney (Option D): Incorrect because CT primarily evaluates vascular anomalies and stones, but does not provide the best cyst visualization for PKD.

questions.text:
​ What is the cause of the following appearance in IVP?

 ​​ ​​
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ureterocoele

Explanation:

Ureterocoele is a congenital abnormality where the lower end of the ureter balloons out and forms a cyst-like structure. In an IVP, ureterocoele can be seen as a filling defect or a dilated portion of the ureter. It may cause obstruction to urine flow and can be associated with hydronephrosis.

Ureterocele

USG showing cystic pouching at left and right ureteral orifices

Bilateral “Cobra head” appearance of distal ureters on X-ray Intravenous Urography

Horseshoe Kidney (Option A) is a congenital condition in which the lower poles of both kidneys are fused together, forming a U-shaped structure. In an Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP), horseshoe kidney may be visualized as a single mass or "horseshoe-shaped" structure in the midline of the abdomen.

Bladder Tumor (Option C): Bladder tumors refer to abnormal growths of tissue in the bladder, which may be benign or malignant (cancerous). In an IVP, bladder tumors can appear as filling defects or irregularities within the bladder. These abnormalities may cause partial or complete obstruction of the bladder outlet, and the IVP can help identify the location, size, and extent of the tumor.

Posterior Urethral Valve (Option D) is a congenital abnormality that occurs in male infants where there is an abnormal fold of tissue in the urethra, obstructing urine flow. In an IVP, the posterior urethral valve may manifest as dilatation of the urethra and the urinary bladder. The IVP can demonstrate the extent of the obstruction, any associated hydronephrosis, and the impact on the urinary tract.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best investigation for detecting ureteric calculi?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option A) NCCT

Explanation

  • NCCT (Option A) is the gold standard for stone detection due to its high accuracy. It finds all stone types, including those not visible on X-ray, and gives crucial details like size, location, and signs of obstruction. It's fast and widely available.

Incorrect Options:

Ureteroscopy (Option B ruled out) offers direct visualization, it's an invasive procedure, typically used for treatment, not initial diagnosis.

X-ray (KUB) (Option C ruled out) is limited; it only shows radiopaque stones, often misses others, and can be obscured by bowel contents. It's mainly for monitoring known stones.

CT scan (Option D ruled out) as a general term implies NCCT for stone detection, as contrast is usually avoided.

questions.text: What is true about the investigation shown below?

choices.text: Non invasive procedure to diagnose PUJ obstruction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non invasive procedure to diagnose PUJ obstruction

Explanation: The image depicts Intravenous Urography (IVU), also called Intravenous Pyelography (IVP).

  • It is a non-invasive imaging technique where IV contrast is injected and serial X-rays are taken to outline the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.
  • It is particularly useful to evaluate anatomy and pathology at the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ), ureter, and collecting system.

Invasive procedure (Option A): IVU is not considered invasive; only involves IV contrast administration.

Gold standard for bladder cancer (Option C): The gold standard for bladder cancer diagnosis is cystoscopy with biopsy, not IVU.

Done percutaneously (Option D): That describes Percutaneous Nephrostography, not IVU.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with chills and rigors. She has acute pain in right flank region. The imaging is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Emphysematous pyelonephritis:

  • Emphysematous pyelonephritis is a severe bacterial infection of the kidney characterized by gas formation within the renal parenchyma and surrounding tissues.
  • It is more common in patients with diabetes and is associated with high mortality.
  • The patient's presentation of chills, rigors, acute right flank pain and the presence of gas within the renal parenchyma on imaging are highly indicative of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

Incorrect options: Option A, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of correct answer.
